awd_titl_txt: Exhibit-Based Public Participation in Social Psychology Research
awd_abstract_narration:
As part of its overall strategy to enhance learning in informal environments, the Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) program seeks to advance new approaches to, and evidence-based understanding of, the design and development of STEM learning in informal environments. This includes providing multiple pathways for broadening access to and engagement in STEM learning experiences, advancing innovative research on and assessment of STEM learning in informal environments, and developing understandings of deeper learning by participants.  The Exploratorium in San Francisco, in collaboration with social science researchers at Arizona State University and Rutgers University, will conduct a two-year Pilots and Feasibility Studies project that will test a new model for integrating museum exhibits with public participation in scientific research, called Exhibit-Based PPSR (E-PPSR).  The team will create a mini-exhibition about social psychology that (a) engages science museum visitors in investigating and reflecting on social factors that promote cooperation or not, (b) builds public awareness of the science of social psychology and (c) generates valid data for academic research in this area. 

The Exploratorium will build on its long history of creating participatory exhibits that engage visiting groups in social science learning and in self-reflective metacognition. This expands beyond the typical lab-in-the-museum in which individual visitors interact with researchers' laptops or simple props. The model takes the exhibit experiences further, injecting the dimension of public participation in social psychology research. By voluntarily and anonymously contributing demographic and response data, large numbers of people from mixed-age groups will help social scientists gain new insights into cooperation among a broader sample of humanity than are usually studied in university labs.  The E-PPSR lab is always available, rather than open only when a researcher is present.  The model also incorporates research on learning and assesses the effect of E-PPSR on social science learning experiences. Do museum visitors build greater conceptual understanding of the social science by contributing to real research and seeing their own responses within the larger dataset? Do they attend more deeply to debriefing activities when they have contributed their own data? The three main deliverables include: 1) a prototype Exhibit-based PPSR laboratory at the Exploratorium comprised of one exhibit for gaining informed consent, three 'Data-Catcher' exhibits modified to record anonymous responses when visitors opt-in to contributing to social psychological research, and one debriefing exhibit. A back-end database will send data to the academic researchers; 2) evaluation studies that test the E-PPSR model. The studies will assess the success of debriefing approaches, the effectiveness of recruitment and the impact of E-PPSR on learning. The team will publish a journal article describing the E-PPSR model and academic research findings. The team will also organize a conference session with others in the museum field who manage in-house academic research laboratories; and 3) a report by the academic partners describing the impact of the project on their research program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Playing Games for Social Science: A New Model for Citizen Science in Museums

Our goal was to create and test a new model for citizen science in museums, called Exhibit-based Public Participation in Scientific Research (E-PPSR for short, see Figure 1). The objectives included:

  • Providing fun learning experiences about the science of cooperation to science museum visitors

  • Inviting science museum visitors to collect and contribute valid data about their own cooperation to the Human Generosity Project, a scientific research study led by university professors

  • Building public awareness and understanding of social science research 

  • Measuring the effect of participating in scientific research on museum visitors' engagement, interest and understanding of social science research.

The Exploratorium created an exhibition, called GameLab, that invites museum visitors to contribute to scientific research on cooperation by playing games at two exhibits (Survival Game and Freeloader). See Figures 2 and 3. The exhibits record the visitors' gameplay for analysis by university researchers studying cooperation. At a final exhibit (the Wrap Up), players can learn more about the research and explore an interactive visualization of their data to compare their own behaviors to everyone else's, thus trying on the (simplified) role of a scientist. Before entering GameLab, participants provide anonymous demographic information about their group size, ages, genders, zip codes and whether their group consisted of family, friends or a mix of both. Each individual in the group gets an RFID bracelet which links their demographic information to their behaviors in the games. 

How does this help university researchers? In their on-campus laboratory, they study only college students. At GameLab, they can study people of all ages, as well as groups composed of family members, friends or strangers. Also, GameLab welcomes many thousands of people per year. Of the 1,815 groups who have entered GameLab so far, 99% reported their age; 94% gave their gender, 85% provided their zip code; and 96% gave their permission to contribute their gameplay data to university research. By vastly increasing the number and diversity of people who contribute to their study, our university partners hope to build a theory of cooperation that applies more broadly. 

How does contributing affect the learning experience?

In addition to creating an educational exhibition and providing valid data for research, the team also tested the impact of contributing to science on participants' learning. To do this, we built GameLab so it could be switched between two conditions: Treatment, where participants' gameplay was captured and sent to university researchers; and Control, where it was not. In the Control mode, there was no mention of contributing to science at all, but the activities people did were identical to those in the Treatment condition. The question was: When people know they are contributing to real social science while playing with exhibits, do they become more interested, spend more time, and learn more about social science than people who are not contributing to science but still playing with the same exhibits?

To find out, we switched GameLab between the two conditions every week for three months, and invited people to take a survey as they left the exhibition. The surveys focused on people's (a) attitudes about the exhibits, (b) overall experience rating, (c) understanding of the exhibits' content, (d) change in perceptions of social science research, and (e) levels of trust in science.

From May to July, 2022, we collected 94 surveys in the Treatment condition and 79 surveys in the Control condition. See Figure 4.

Contributing to science enhances learning

Comparing people in the Treatment condition to people in the Control condition, we found that the Treatment group had significantly more positive attitudes towards the Wrap Up exhibit, but not towards Survival Game or Freeloader. Also, people in the Treatment condition spent significantly more time playing Survival Game than people in the Control condition. There were no differences in how well people in each condition understood the social science content of the games. However, people in the Treatment condition reported a greater increase in their positive perceptions of social science research than people in the Control condition. Interestingly, the biggest differences were between people in each condition who didn't trust science very much, or who didn't have a very good overall experience in GameLab. See Figure 5. It seems that having people participate in scientific research, rather than simply learn about it, may overcome low levels of trust in science, and even may overcome a less-than-stellar learning experience. 

This pilot study needs to be repeated with other exhibitions and larger numbers of surveys. But if the results hold up, they would give a boost to the idea that citizen science confers its own educational benefits for the people who participate.
